What impact has the #coronavirus had on financial stability? What are the key vulnerabilities facing the eurozone financial system and which challenges lie ahead for its recovery? 

Watch our video and read the Financial Stability Review to find out https://t.co/mehVWVuYf2 https://t.co/JjbJGdKwOk
Euro money market statistics (second maintenance period 2020) https://t.co/2xPAJCiRou

Thanks for sharing, @economicssummit. We look forward to many questions! https://t.co/YdVO1tYRPa
The Financial Stability Review will be published in full on Tuesday, 26 May at 15:00 CET

Did volatility-targeting strategies amplify market moves in March? Could lower dividend payouts help improve bank resilience? What might money-market fund stress mean for the financial system? Find out in a preview of our Financial Stability Review https://t.co/hrCsylg1ql https://t.co/Hb5qtSKDzJ

The challenge for central banks is to ensure that monetary policy strategies successfully protect the medium-term inflation aim. Accordingly, the monetary policy strategy review remains a high priority for the ECB https://t.co/ub7OtANuTU 5/5
The convergence of monetary policy regimes has played a central role in the convergence of medium-term inflation outcomes 4/5

The contribution of economic globalisation to higher inflation co-movements may differ between phases in which globalisation acts as anti-inflationary force and phases in which globalisation acts as pro-inflationary force 3/5

Structural change associated with globalisation may have contributed to greater co-movement in headline inflation outcomes, but economic globalisation can also be a source of divergent inflationary pressures, especially during adjustment phases 2/5

(THREAD) Average inflation rates have declined and shown lower volatility in recent decades, says ECB Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. Common shocks, structural changes and monetary policy regimes have contributed to the observed high correlation of inflation across countries 1/5 https://t.co/Btnm2dpb06

Panetta sul Mezzogiorno: ha potenzialità inespresse, il motore della sua economia richiede una spinta. Occorre agire anche valutando, in accordo con la Commissione europea, interventi sulla tassazione dell’attività produttiva del Sud per rilanciarne economia e occupazione 6/6

Panetta sull'importanza del capitale umano in Italia: questa crisi ci da l’opportunità, dopo tante tragedie, di ripartire migliorando la capacitá competitiva, stimolando gli investimenti in tecnologia e formazione di capitale umano 5/6

Panetta su proposta Merkel-Macron: è un’ottima proposta, un notevole passo in avanti nella consapevolezza dell’esigenza di finanziare la ripresa. Adesso dobbiamo ripartire tutti insieme, superare la fase di difficoltà e tornare a crescere 4/6

Panetta sulla risposta a livello europeo: la politica monetaria è fondamentale ma da sola non può risollevare l’economia europea. Occorre l’intervento di altre politiche. Le autorità europee hanno approvato e stanno approvando delle misure importanti 3/6

Panetta sulla politica monetaria adottata dalla BCE: Siamo intervenuti per mantenere acceso il motore dell’economia dando finanziamenti alle banche a tassi ancora più negativi ma solo a condizione che quei fondi venissero poi utilizzati per famiglie e imprese 2/6

(THREAD) Adesso la nostra economia deve ripartire e tornare a crescere, afferma Fabio Panetta, Membro del Comitato esecutivo della BCE, in un'intervista con #RCSAcademy e @Corriere. Guarda il video dell'intervento qui https://t.co/Vc8g7P2eqw  1/6 https://t.co/X7cr5OKply

The ECB seeks comments from the banking industry and other stakeholders on a draft guide on how it expects banks to manage and disclose climate-related and environmental risks. Comments can be sent until 25 September 2020. Read more https://t.co/8R4kEpJD9T https://t.co/Zec4mXSDTU

Applications for our Women in Economics #Scholarship are now open. We are offering grants and a study visit at the ECB to female #economics students. Like last year’s winners pictured here, you need to be an EU national with top undergraduate marks  https://t.co/EZafLxy7FP https://t.co/aGesR8rylD

Watch live from 16:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane participates in a webinar hosted by the Institute for Monetary and Financial Stability @IMFS_Frankfurt on policy responses to the coronavirus pandemic https://t.co/leghzWvL03 https://t.co/o45uIWSe7p
You can also find out more about the measures we’ve taken to tackle the economic impact of the coronavirus on our new webpage available in EU languages https://t.co/VbqKgbBIYd

How is the coronavirus pandemic affecting the economy? Which sectors have been hit hardest? What is the ECB doing to limit the economic impact of the crisis? Tune into our latest #podcast episode with ECB Chief Economist Philip R. Lane to find out https://t.co/i0qOyn9bqs https://t.co/AL1t11D5h5
Results of the March 2020 survey on credit terms and conditions in euro-denominated securities financing and over-the-counter derivatives markets (SESFOD) https://t.co/rgi5o9Ew2W

Lagarde on the importance of European values: Our growth models should evolve in light of climate change. Inequality is dangerous. Globalisation should be more respectful of human beings. Europe holds fundamental values that can inspire -it’s up to us to defend them 8/8

Lagarde on central bank independence: Europe is built on a clear legal architecture. This includes the independence of the ECB, which is guaranteed by the EU Treaty and is a pillar of German monetary thinking. This independence is the ECB’s strength for achieving its mandate 7/8

Lagarde on proposal for European recovery fund: The proposals from the French and German leaders are ambitious, targeted and welcome. They allow a substantial amount of direct support to be provided to the most affected countries and are testament to a spirit of solidarity 6/8

Lagarde on joint fiscal support: Some countries do not have the fiscal headroom to do what is needed to restart their economies. We need a European programme of rapid and robust fiscal stimulus to restore symmetry. Such collective support is in the interest of all countries 5/8

Lagarde on increasing the PEPP: We will not hesitate to adjust the size, duration and composition of our pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) to the extent necessary. We will use all the flexibility within our mandate 4/8

Lagarde on the ECB’s mandate: Price stability is at the heart of our mandate. We must ensure there is as much accommodation as needed to stabilise inflation and the economy, and that our monetary policy is transmitted properly to all sectors and all eurozone countries 3/8

Lagarde on the current crisis: The economic shock the eurozone is facing is huge – unprecedented in peacetime. We need to counter it with determination to help our economies recover as quickly as possible 2/8

(THREAD) In an interview with @LesEchos, @Corriere, @handelsblatt and @elmundoes, President @Lagarde discusses the eurozone’s economic recovery from the coronavirus and the action needed at European level to secure it https://t.co/BuAXIOTcrj 1/8 https://t.co/4rUu5jLXBy

Banks have become exceptionally reliant on IT systems during the coronavirus pandemic. The more they rely on IT systems, the more exposed they are to IT and cyber risk. Ensuring strong IT and cyber security is therefore vital. Read more in the Newsletter https://t.co/v4GeuzR6g4 https://t.co/zI1NFyxkdQ
Lane: Our aim is to ensure that financial conditions are appropriate for all markets and to help counter rather than amplify the impact of the pandemic shock to the economy.

Lane: If we see that financial conditions are too tight or the pressure on individual bond markets is not reflecting economic fundamentals, we can adjust the size or duration of our purchases, which we can anyway allocate flexibly over time and market segments.

Lane: The precise configuration of the PEPP is guided by two things: improving monetary conditions and stabilising financial markets. The exact figure is of secondary importance. We are constantly assessing whether we are doing enough and if there is a risk of instability.

In an interview with @el_pais, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane underlines that the ECB is a goal-oriented institution and that this applies to our monetary policy measures. Read the full interview

https://t.co/GgdZ2wdP8x (ES)

ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria discusses how European banks are managing during the coronavirus crisis, whether they are using the announced supervisory relief measures, what risks lie ahead and what it all means for Europe https://t.co/eoIiGzmzlb https://t.co/GxcVVL91gx

Ultimately, these measures aim to increase the share of women holding positions at analyst, expert and managerial levels to 51%, 47% and 36% respectively. We will review the targets in 2022 and 2024, adjusting or introducing measures where necessary 3/3 https://t.co/gFszfzi4mS

To reach this overall increase and create a more gender-balanced workplace, the ECB plans to fill at least 50% of new open positions at analyst, expert and management levels with women #genderbalance 2/3

[THREAD] We have launched new #gendertargets as part of our efforts to foster a diverse work environment. The strategy includes targets for hiring and promoting women, as well as for an overall increase in female staff by the end of 2026. Read more https://t.co/p1aHPlLkMg 1/3 https://t.co/zAR9kSHCop

The lockdown measures to counter the #coronavirus are affecting consumption as households spend less on energy and more on food and housing. The lockdown also poses challenges for measuring inflation. Find out why https://t.co/C1775oZXgD #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/qovt5S6eoG

How are the lockdown measures to counter the #coronavirus affecting people’s consumption? What’s the economic impact of the coronavirus shock? Find out the answer to these questions and more in our latest #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/jAmKKARVtZ https://t.co/G42eZJJ33M

Al momento stiamo attraversando un grave shock economico, afferma il Membro del Comitato esecutivo della BCE Fabio Panetta in un'intervista con @derStandardat. Come prima cosa dobbiamo soprattutto mantenere la capacità produttiva dell’area dell’euro. Leggi https://t.co/XxUrsYbMmq

Wir erleben gerade einen schweren wirtschaftlichen Schock, sagt EZB Vorstandsmitglied Fabio Panetta in einem Interview mit @derStandardat. Die wichtigste Aufgabe ist es nun, die Produktionskapazitäten in der Eurozone aufrechtzuerhalten. Zum Interview https://t.co/Fh7yzeTgbK

Panetta: What matters now is stabilising the economy. Next comes a phase in which we need investment. Some countries will need to invest in healthcare infrastructure. And, as always, innovation and education remain central. Read the full interview https://t.co/xl1cFO0Zcw 6/6

Panetta: One of the biggest challenges is to prevent the eurozone from emerging from this crisis with even more divergence. It is in every country’s own interest to secure the recovery across the eurozone and to collectively provide resources to that end 5/6
Panetta: We have all the necessary tools, we are using them decisively and we are determined to continue doing so 4/6

Panetta: We will do everything necessary to fulfil our price stability mandate. We remain determined not to tolerate any tightening of financing conditions for as long as the economic damage caused by the coronavirus persists 3/6

Panetta: By improving financing conditions for all sectors of the economy, our monetary policy complements and reinforces European and national measures. The more we protect our productive capacity today, the easier it will be to manage public debt in the future 2/6

(THREAD) We are currently going through a severe economic shock, says ECB Executive Board member Fabio Panetta in an interview with @derStandardat. The first and most important thing we have to do is to maintain the euro area’s productive capacity 1/6 https://t.co/hSUMzJkt6q

How do negative interest rates affect the economy? They help ease financing conditions and spur loan creation, which supports the economy and ultimately contributes to price stability https://t.co/U4eX2mzqbt #EconomicBulletin #negativeinterestrates https://t.co/otjUeL5vbN
Euro area securities issues statistics (March 2020) https://t.co/AexuvC3Nrx
Read the full interview on our website in English https://t.co/rH4ngUuXeM and in Dutch https://t.co/0z2VPuH5dL (4/4)

Lane on coronabonds: They are about the joint issuance of new debt, not about the refinancing of old debts. Evidence indicates there would be strong demand for coronabonds from global investors and it would be a cheaper source of financing for many countries (3/4)

Lane on the economic impact of the coronavirus: Our scenarios factor in a contraction of between 5% and 12% in 2020. We are now in the trough, but I expect the data to improve over the summer, even though people have now accepted that the virus will continue for some time (2/4)

Economic activity fell sharply in the euro area in March 2020 as a result of the #coronavirus pandemic: the containment measures have affected manufacturing and services activity in all euro area countries. Find out more in our latest #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/0loxpYWxKZ https://t.co/0fnauFdT8a

The focus will be on how banks manage the risks to capital and liquidity arising from the crisis. Our intention is to keep Pillar 2 requirements and guidance stable, unless changes are warranted for individual banks (2/2) https://t.co/uF6V8ekhKH

ECB Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul writes in the Supervision Blog that the 2020 supervisory review will take a pragmatic approach while aiming to maintain a clear and accurate view of banks’ soundness (1/2) https://t.co/TcqPt2zLqg

The #coronavirus shock differs greatly from a typical aggregate shock, making its economic impact very uncertain. The impact will depend on the length of lockdowns and the effectiveness of policies supporting households and firms https://t.co/bUxuQUtTZM #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/0YiqN2AAzg

Mersch: We will only introduce a digital currency if we become firmly convinced that it is both necessary and proportionate to fulfil our tasks. If and when the time comes, we want to be ready – and we will be ready 3/3 https://t.co/p61aUhA1gL

Mersch: We closely follow technological developments and reflect on the type of money and payments that are best suited to the needs of an increasingly digital economy. Whether and when CBDCs become more of a policy debate will largely depend on the preferences of households 2/3

An ECB digital currency: a flight of fancy? At the Consensus 2020 virtual conference, Executive Board Member Yves Mersch discussed what is shaping the ECB’s work on central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) and the importance of being ready for change 1/3 https://t.co/p61aUhA1gL https://t.co/XMJIPO9URr

Today marks the 70th anniversary of the Schuman Declaration that set the stage for the European Union. Coronavirus is our “Schuman moment,” says President @Lagarde. We are being asked to act, as those before us did, by strengthening Europe. Read more https://t.co/Ironphqbn6 https://t.co/6DBDoHnkPJ

Read the full speech https://t.co/ufKssHzf7b

#SOUCOVID19

Lagarde: In sum, this is our generation’s “Schuman moment”. We have been passed the baton of European integration. We are seeing our de facto solidarity all around us. And we are being asked to act, as those before us did, by strengthening Europe in response.
